column1: {{quote|The [[Big Folk]] and the [[Little Folk]] (as they called one another) were on friendly terms
column2: minding their own affairs in their own ways
column3: but both rightly regarding themselves as necessary parts of the Bree-folk.|[[At the Sign of the Prancing Pony]]}}

column1: The '''Bree-landers''' or '''Bree-folk''' were the peoples who inhabited the [[Bree-land]]
column2: [[Men]] and [[Hobbits]] who lived peaceably side by side. These two races
column3: identified individually as the [[Bree-hobbits]] (the [[Little Folk]]) and the [[Men of Bree|Bree-men]] (the [[Big Folk]]).<ref name=pony>{{FR|I9}}</ref>

column1: Their main settlements were four communities scattered around the [[Bree-hill]]: [[Bree]] itself
They were a generally friendly folk
column2: at least until the upheavals brought about by the [[War of the Ring]]. They had some dealings with the [[Shire-hobbits]]
column3: though the road between Bree and their 'colony' of the Shire was less travelled by the late [[Third Age]].

column1: Bree measured time with the [[Bree Calendar]]<ref>{{App|Calendars}}</ref> which is obviously a [[Hobbit]]ish localization of the [[King's Reckoning]].<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Andreas Moehn]]|articlename=The Reckoning of Time|articleurl=http://lalaith.vpsurf.de/Tolkien/Time.html|website=Lalaith}}</ref>
They maintained their own dialect of [[Westron]]. The "Bree-dialect" did not use words like "history" and "geography" much<ref name=pony/> betraying a disinterest in lore and the outside world.
